answers.text: defining as black, persons with any known African ancestry

qas.question: What did some courts call the one-drop rule?

answers.text: meaning that racially mixed persons were assigned the status of the socially subordinate group

qas.question: When was the one-drop rule in effect?

answers.text: black, persons with any known African ancestry.
racially mixed persons were assigned the status of the socially subordinate group.

qas.question: Why were laws like the one drop rule enacted?

answers.text: In their attempt to ensure white supremacy decades after emancipation

qas.question: What made the one drop rule stricter than rules in the 19th century?

answers.text: it ignored the many mixed families in the state and went against commonly accepted social rules of judging a person by appearance and association.

qas.question: In the early 1900s, what was did black mean in southern states?

answers.text: persons with any known African ancestry

qas.question: Prior to the 1900s, what was the socially accepted rule for racial interpretation?

answers.text: judging a person by appearance and association.

plausible_answers.text: persons with any known African ancestry

context: <a6_0>In their attempt to ensure white supremacy decades after emancipation<a6_0/>, <a3_0>in the early 20th century<a3_0/>, most southern states <b13_0>created <b14_0>laws based on <a11_0>the one-drop rule<b14_0/><b13_0/><a11_0/>, <a0_0>defining as <a4_0>black, <a8_0><b15_0>persons with any known African ancestry<b15_0/><a8_0/><a0_0/>.<a4_0/> This was a stricter interpretation than what had prevailed in the 19th century; <a7_0>it ignored the many mixed families in the state and went against commonly accepted social rules of <a9_0>judging a person by appearance and association.<a9_0/><a7_0/> Some courts called it <a1_0>"<a12_0><b16_0>the traceable amount rule<b16_0/><a12_0/>."<a1_0/> Anthropologists called it an example of <a10_0>a <b17_0>hypodescent<b17_0/> rule<a10_0/>, <a2_0>meaning that <a5_0>racially mixed persons were assigned the status of the socially subordinate group<a2_0/>.
